awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Functional genomics of plumage ornaments in a warbler
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the grand challenges in animal biology is to understand the influence of genes on the development of phenotypic and behavioral traits. The plumage of birds encompasses a spectacular array of ornamental plumages long appreciated for their beauty, yet we know little about how the color of plumage patches or their size is influenced by genes. It is generally thought that the plumage color of male birds is a signal of quality to females choosing mates. Several hypotheses have now been proposed linking the size and color of plumage ornaments to various physiological and genetic pathways related to health, including those involved in cellular metabolism, growth, oxidative stress and immunity. Any one pathway could provide a general explanation for how bird colors signal quality in males, but these genetic pathways may interact in complex ways that can only be understood using genome-wide analysis techniques. Here the researchers plan to examine these pathways using next generation gene sequencing of the genome of a brightly colored warbler. The types of pigments in this bird (black colored melanin and yellow colored carotenoids) are widespread across species and, thus, will provide a general model for many researchers studying the development of colorful ornaments.  As part of the project the researchers will conduct workshops on genomics at local colleges, at an international behavior meeting and, in Belize, for a local zoo and local conservationists.


This study will use genomic analyses to test several recent hypotheses for the genetic basis of ornament expression in a warbler, the common yellowthroat. This warbler is one of a few species of birds in which females are known to choose mates based on ornamental traits that are associated with indices of fitness. Interestingly, sexual selection targets different ornaments in different populations of the common yellowthroat. In Wisconsin, females prefer males with larger black masks, whereas in New York females prefer males with larger, more colorful yellow bibs. The investigators have already shown that mask size in Wisconsin and bib color in New York are honest signals of similar aspects of male quality in each population. Based on these results, the investigators plan to use a genomics approach to determine if: 1) elaborate ornaments are related to the expression of genes in growth, immunity and oxidative stress pathways, as predicted by recent hypotheses, and 2) if these traits exhibit molecular parallelism where the same genetic pathways are most closely associated with the ornament preferred by females in each location. To maximize the probability of finding differences and to expand the tests of parallelism, the study will also incorporate geographic comparisons with other subspecies and a closely-related species in Belize, which have larger differences in ornament size and color.

por.por_cntn:
Large and showy male traits, such as the bright colors and long tails found in some birds are thought to advertise the quality of males, particularly to females that are choosing mates. These extravagant ornamental traits may also be advertising a male’s genetic characteristics, such as his ability to resist disease.  Thus females my prefer to mate with males that have extravagant ornaments because their offspring are also likely to inherit superior genetic traits. However, this “good genes” hypothesis has been controversial, partly because the genomic methods necessary to test it have only become available recently. This study used genome-wide analyses to test several recent hypotheses for the genetic basis of ornament size in a warbler, the common yellowthroat. These hypotheses propose a link between the size of ornaments and various genetic functions, including immunity, the efficiency of cellular metabolism, and resistance to oxidative stress. As predicted, the size of male ornaments in common yellowthroats was positively related to genes involved in immunity, cellular efficiency, and oxidative stress. Thus ornaments appear to be signals of the quality of males at a core genetic level.

Interestingly, the study also found similar relationships between ornaments and genes in two populations in which females prefer different male ornaments. In Wisconsin, females prefer to mate with males that have larger black masks, whereas in New York females prefer to mate with males that have larger yellow bibs. Despite the difference in preferred ornaments in the two populations, each of the ornaments signaled similar aspects of male quality at the level of genetic functions (e.g., immunity and resistance to oxidative stress). Note that the non-preferred ornament in each population (mask in NY and bib in WI) generally failed to show these relationships. This parallelism between populations at the functional level provides the flexibility for different ornaments to be used as signals of similar aspects of male quality. Ultimately, this could facilitate switches in female preferences between ornaments, leading to the early stages of population divergence and speciation.  Thus, the study provides support for good genes hypotheses (in general) and a potential mechanism for the evolution of multiple ornaments (in this case both a large black mask and yellow bib). To expand the tests of parallelism, the study also incorporated geographic comparisons with other subspecies of common yellowthroats and a closely-related species (gray-crowned yellowthroat) in Belize, which have larger differences in ornament size and color.

The project also contributed to training other researchers through a workshop on genomics at the Animal Behavior Society meeting in Milwaukee, an online workshop on analyzing genetic polymorphisms for Polish researchers, and a hands-on workshop on conservation genetics for curators and staff at the Belize zoo.  The project also led to the development of an annotated, chromosome-level genome of the common yellowthroat in collaboration with the Vertebrate Genomes Project. Annotated genomes of wild birds are still relatively rare and will be useful for others studying songbird genomes. For example, we used this genome and others to study the evolution of duplication in the major histocompatibility genes (MHC) of birds. This study resulted in a database of MHC sequences that can be used for future comparative analyses of birds.
